The program seeks to help the state government of Mizoram (SGM) to 
create fiscal space by (i)  enhancing tax and nontax revenue measures 
and rationalizing expenditures; (ii) bringing about service improvements 
in  two  key  sectors  (health  and  education)  in  a  cost-effective  manner;  
(iii)  ensuring  better  debt  management;  (iv)  reforming  the  state  pension 
system;  and  (v)  restructuring  public  sector  enterprises,  including 
through closure, as needed. 
 
The rationale for the program is based on two underlying factors: (i) the 
political commitment of SGM to bring about necessary fiscal reforms to 
set the fiscal situation on a trajectory that is balanced, sustainable, and 
geared  to  meeting  the  long-term  needs  of  the  population  of  the  state; 
and (ii) the need of the state economy for a program that takes a holistic 
view of fiscal reforms ranging from a focus on macro and, for example, 
medium-term expenditure frameworks to a focus on micro reforms such 
as ensuring that sector reforms contribute to improved service delivery 
and enhanced fiscal space. The program directly addresses key issues 
facing  SGM  as  it  tries  to  direct  the  economy  on  a  more  sustainable 
development path. 
 
The  impact  of  the  program  will  be  evident  in  SGM  increasing 
investments  of  public  funds  to  improve  inclusive  human  and  social 
development  in  the  state.  The  program  seeks  an  outcome  of  greater 
fiscal  space  in,  and  financial  flexibility  of,  the  government  budget 
resulting  from:  (i)  increased  tax  and  nontax  revenues;  (ii)  rationalized 
expenditures  in  areas such  as  pensions  and  public  sector  enterprises, 
and  through  the  adoption  of  medium-term  expenditure  frameworks  in

A loan of $94,000,000 from the ordinary capital resources (OCR) of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  be  provided  to  India  under  ADB’s 
London  interbank  offered rate (LIBOR)-based  lending facility. The  loan 
will have a 15-year term including a grace period of 3 years, an interest 
rate determined in accordance with ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility, 
a  commitment  charge of  0.15%  per  annum,  and  such  other terms  and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement.  
 
The loan will be released in three tranches: (i) $47,000,000 for the first 
tranche, (ii) $40,000,000 for the second tranche, and (iii) $7,000,000 for 
the third tranche. The first tranche will be released upon fulfillment of all 
agreed conditions for the first tranche and following effectiveness of the 
loan.  The  second  tranche  will  be  disbursed  16  months  after  loan 
effectiveness  upon  satisfactory  fulfillment  of  the  corresponding  tranche 
release  conditions  (or  earlier  than  16  months  if  the  conditions  have 
been  met).  The  third  tranche  will  be  disbursed  14  months  after  the 
second  tranche,  subject  to  satisfactory  fulfillment  of  the  corresponding 
tranche  release  conditions  (or  earlier  than  14  months  if  the  conditions 
have been met).  
 
The  Government  of  India  (Government)  will  relend  10%  of  the  loan 
proceeds  in  local  currency  to  SGM.  The  relending  terms  will  be  in 
accordance with the Government’s arrangement for transfer of external 
assistance  to  SGM  and  it  will  be  treated  as  additional  to  Government 
transfers. The remaining 90% of the loan proceeds will be provided as 
grants. 
 
The program period will be from August 2009 (or loan effectiveness) to 
July 2012 (or 36 months after loan effectiveness).

The benefits of the program are expected to be evident in the following: 
(i)  availability  of  more  resources  to  invest  in  social  and  economic 
infrastructure; (ii) more efficient allocation of budget resources to social 
sectors  given  the  application  of  medium-term  expenditure  frameworks; 
(iii)  ability  of  SGM,  in  the  long  term,  to  place  its  fiscal  affairs  on  a 
sounder  footing  that  can  sustain  investments  for  more  rapid  and 
inclusive  growth;  and  (iv)  greater  access  to,  and  quality  of,  services  in 
the education and health sectors to the population of Mizoram.  
 
Program  success  depends  on  the  continued  strong  commitment  of 
SGM  to  fiscal  reforms  and  to  the  broader  governance  issues  of 
transparency  in  fiscal  matters.  However,  the  possibility  remains  that 
current  measures  and  reform  efforts,  including  insufficient  capacity  in 
specific  implementing  government  agencies  to  carry  out  the  reforms, 
may  not  be  sustained.  These  risks  will  be  mitigated  by  (i)  continued 
policy  dialogue  with  SGM  as  well  as  with  the  Government,  and  
(ii) specific technical assistance (TA) and capacity development support 
for  the  weak  implementing  agencies.  For  its  part,  SGM  has  fully 
committed to this reform agenda, as demonstrated in its ability to meet 
all the first tranche conditions of the program. 
 
The  key  assumptions  inherent  in  the  program  are  that  (i)  SGM 
commitment  to  reforms  across  the  various sectors  (including  reform  of 
public  sector  enterprises)  will  continue,  (ii)  the  Thirteenth  Finance 
Commission does not alter the existing trend of fiscal devolution to the 
states, (iii) capacity development plans are in place and are funded and 
used, (iv) SGM is able to implement the voluntary retirement scheme for 
school teachers in an impartial and transparent manner, (v) the greater 
fiscal  space  will  result  in  reorientation  of  expenditure  into  social  and 
economic  infrastructure,  and  (vi)  any  developments  that  take  place  in 
the  short  to  medium  term  will  not  adversely  affect  the  program  in  any 
substantive manner.

Regarded  as  a  small  state  (with  a  population  of  approximately  1  million  people),

The large and increasing fiscal imbalance in the state during the late 1990s and the early 
part  of  this  decade  became  a  matter  of  serious  policy  concern.  The  uncontrolled  fiscal  deficit 
and  increased  resort  to  borrowings  have  made  the  task  of  bringing  about  macroeconomic 
stabilization much more difficult and complex. High debt stock, in turn, led to further escalation 
of current expenditure due to higher interest payments. Thus, the state is trapped in a  vicious 
cycle of debt-deficit dynamics, and one of the fundamental reasons for initiating fiscal reforms is 
to reduce the Mizoram debt stock to a sustainable amount.

But the underestimation caused by forecasting errors is mixed with another factor, which 
makes assessing the quality of forecasting difficult. Because the state‘s public finances are so 
heavily  dependent  on  central  transfers  (of  which  a  large  part  is  difficult  to  forecast  with  any 
confidence because of their irregular nature), the  base estimates are deliberately conservative 
in deference to financial prudence. If and when SGM is certain that additional transfers may be 
forthcoming, it completes a midcourse adjustment by introducing a supplementary budget. If the 
central transfers are not so large in a particular year, this procedure ensures that expenditures 
do not rise too much relative to receipts. Thus, the regular use of supplementary budgets (that is 
usually frowned upon as an indication of weak expenditure control) is, in fact, a tool of cautious 
budgetary  policy  in  Mizoram.  Given  this  tendency,  the  comparison  of  actual  budgetary 
outcomes  with  base  estimates  shows  not  only  a  forecasting  error  but  also  an  element  of 
deliberate  underestimation—disentangling  the  two  elements  is  difficult.  This  is  complicated  by 
the possibility that the difference could also be partly ascribed to inadequate budget execution, 
which could have actually gone either way—judging its direction is impossible.

2. 
Key  Issues.  Two  key  issues  dominate  the  poverty  aspects  of  fiscal  management 
reforms: (i) Human poverty as distinct from income poverty: poverty has to be seen not only in

macroeconomic and fiscal reforms is only possible when the policy reform agenda is backed by 
strong capacity of government departments to deliver on the reform agenda.

low-income groups; (ii) proper debt management and rationalization of expenditures mean the 
fiscal  space  for  greater  social  spending  directly  impacts  poor  people;  and  (iii)  the  impacts  of 
social investments in health and education are more directly visible on the poor.

education sectors (including introduction of the merit principle in the school system); (ii) in the medium-term, SGM will be better able to channel resources for social 
development purposes given that ADB assistance will have enabled it to create the necessary fiscal space, which will free up investment resources; and (iii) finally, 
in  the  long  term,  a  rigorous  expenditure  framework  in  the  health  and  education  sectors  will  ensure  that  the  government  effectively  targets  resources  to  desired 
outcomes with assured amount of resources. All these will ultimately, albeit in an indirect manner, have a positive impact on the poor. The conceptual basis of all 
these three points is in the link between fiscal reforms leading to macroeconomic stability and pro-poor growth and social and economic development.
